pages.name: Introductory Page
pages.introText:
How can you tell a story about motion without using words?

The picture at right communicates direction of traffic using recognizable symbols. In this activity, you will explore how motions in two opposite directions appear on a position-time graph. By doing so, you will learn conventional methods of motion storytelling and analysis.

pages.name: Prediction Page
pages.introText:
Let’s start by demonstrating what you already know about representing motion on a graph. Imagine a straight walking path that is 4 meters long.

Point A is at the 0-meter mark.

Point B is at the 4-meter mark.

pages.name: Motion Sensor Page
pages.introText: Let’s practice collecting data with the motion sensor so you can see whether your sketches were accurate. You will walk on a 4-meter walking path like the one described earlier.

pages.name: Replay Page
pages.introText:
To the right are your predictions for walking away and toward point B.

Now that you "have the hang of it," you will walk with the sensor to see if your sketches of forward and backward motion are correct.

pages.name: Replay Page
pages.introText: At right is the data you just collected with the motion sensor.

pages.name: Replay Page
pages.introText: At right is a position-time graph created by someone walking in front of a motion sensor.

pages.name: Replay Page
pages.introText: Now you will collect and analyze your own data once again.

pages.name: Replay Page
pages.introText: To the right, two different data sets are plotted on the same graph.

pages.name: Replay Page
pages.introText: Look at the position-time graph to the right. You are going to recreate this graph as closely as possible by walking in front of the motion sensor to collect position and time data.

pages.name: Replay Page
pages.introText: To the right are the sketches you drew at the beginning of this activity.

steps.beforeText:
In the top-right area, draw a graph of someone walking at a slow, steady pace from point A to point B between 0 and 15 seconds.

Click the Clear button if you want to try again
In the bottom-right area, draw a graph of someone walking at a slow, steady pace from point B to point A between 0 and 15 seconds. Click Next when you are done.

Place the sensor at the 0-meter mark.

Stand near the sensor. When you are ready, have your partner click Start to record the position and time data for your movements.

Walk on the path for 15 seconds. Try different kinds of motions (walking fast, slow, forward, backward…)

Click Clear if you want to try again.

How are different motions represented on a position-time graph? (For example, what does the graph look like when you are standing still, walking forward ...?)

Try to use some of the following words: slope, flat, upward, downward, curved, straight, steep, gradual, line, curve.

First, stand close to the sensor, near the 0-meter mark.

When you are ready, have your partner click Start to record the position and time data for your movements.

Walk on the path at a slow, steady pace, away from the sensor, for 15 seconds.

To make the second graph, stand approximately 4 meters away from the sensor on the path.

When you are ready, have your partner click Start to record the position and time data for your movements.

Walk on the path at the same slow, steady pace, toward the sensor, for 15 seconds.
How closely do the graphs of your data match your original predictions?
How are the two position-time graphs similar to each other?
How does motion away from the sensor differ from motion toward the sensor on a position-time graph?
What happened at the red point (the y-intercept for this motion)?
What happened at the red point (the y-intercept for this motion)?
steps.afterText: Incorrect. Look at the walker's position at the red point, and select another answer.

steps.beforeText: What happened at the red point (the y-intercept for this motion)?
steps.afterText: Incorrect. Think about what happened to the walker's position after this point, and select another answer.

steps.beforeText: What happened at the red point (the y-intercept for this motion)?
steps.afterText: Incorrect. Look at the walker's direction after the red point, and select another answer.

steps.beforeText: Correct! At this point, the walker was 4 meters away, getting ready to walk toward the sensor.

Stand at a starting point other than the 0-meter mark.

When you are ready, have your partner click Start to record the position and time data for your movements.

Walk on the path for 15 seconds, experimenting with different directions and speeds.
What is the significance of the y-intercept (the y-value of the point where the graph crosses the y-axis) of the position-time graph?
Explain how the graph conveys how fast you walked.
How is direction represented on the graph?
Which of the following motion scenarios could have resulted in this graph?
Which of the following motion scenarios could have resulted in this graph?
steps.afterText: Incorrect. Two data sets are represented on one graph. Analyze each set of data, and select another answer.

steps.beforeText: Which of the following motion scenarios could have resulted in this graph?
steps.afterText: Incorrect. Figure out where each person started and ended, and select another answer.

steps.beforeText: Which of the following motion scenarios could have resulted in this graph?
steps.afterText: Incorrect. Think about the direction each walker moved from the starting point, and select another answer.

steps.beforeText: Still incorrect. Both walkers started 2 meters away. Then, one walked toward the sensor for 20 seconds, while the other walked away from the sensor during the same 20 seconds.
Correct! Both walkers started 2 meters away. Then, one walked toward the sensor for 20 seconds, while the other walked away from the sensor during the same 20 seconds.

Move to your starting point and, when you are ready, have your partner click Start to record the data for your movements.

Walk on the path for 15 seconds while trying to match the given graph.

How closely does your graph match the given graph? What could you have done to match the given graph more closely?

Try to use some of the following words: fast, slow, toward, away.
Write down 3 things you have learned about motion since you started this activity.
Describe 1 type of motion you would like to try with the motion sensor.

fieldChoicesList: The walker was 4 meters away, getting ready to walk toward the sensor.
The walker was closest to the motion sensor, getting ready to walk away from the sensor.
The walker was 4 meters away from the motion sensor and did not move.
The walker was 4 meters away from the motion sensor, getting ready to walk away from the sensor.
My friend and I stood 2 meters away from the sensor. Together, we walked away from the sensor for 20 seconds.
My friend and I stood 2 meters away from the sensor. I walked away from the sensor for 20 seconds while my friend walked toward the sensor for 20 seconds.
I started at the sensor and walked away from the sensor for 20 seconds. My friend started 2 meters away from the sensor and walked away from the sensor for 20 seconds.
I started at the sensor and walked away from the sensor for 20 seconds. My friend started 2 meters away from the sensor and walked toward the sensor for 20 seconds.
